column1: The current UV levels in more detail
The table above shows all the output from the UV meter, the values and their units are explained below:

This is the instantaneous UV intensity at the time shown in the table.  The intensity is measured in MED/Hr.  One MED (Minimum Erythemal Dose) is the dose of UV required to produce slight redness in an average fair skinned person.  However this does not necessarily mean that one hour of exposure at one MED/Hr will cause redness, as the MED is calibrated over much longer time periods, and also minor variations in skin type can have a large effect on skin response.

The UV index is the internationally agreed standard on UV level reporting and is the same UV index that is seen on all the weather forecasts.  The affect of the UV index on different skin types is summarised in the table:
• Category 2 "Tanners": most uk non-indigenous and non-naturally pigmented groups.
• Category 3 "Naturally Brown": mostly Asian and middle and south American groups.
The detector is maintained at or around 25 °C by a peltier heat pump, in order to reduce any temperature dependant drifts.
The data logger records a reading from the sensor once every ten minutes.  This figure shows the total dosage during the last ten minutes in MED.
This is the total dose detected for this calendar day (starting at midnight GMT) in MED.
This is the total dose received since the detectors memory was last reset, usually the beginning of the month.
